repnme.cdata!:
Cutting the red tape boosts business
            environment in Nicaragua

abstracts.cdata!:
The competitiveness project was designed
            to present and test options for improving the business
            environment in Nicaragua and to pilot new business
            development services (BDS), especially through developing
            sectoral clusters geographic concentrations of businesses
            and organizations in related industries that allowed small
            and medium producers and processors to get access to the
            services they needed, and to influence policy and research
            agenda to respond to their demands. The project facilitated
            private sector development in Nicaragua by dramatically
            simplifying business regulations and laws, strengthening
            institutions, developing industry clusters, promoting
            exports, attracting foreign direct investment, and piloting
            sustainable BDS. International Development Association (IDA)
            will continue to support this work through the enhanced
            competitiveness project, which will help strengthen
            institutions and provide technical support and matching
            grants to the private sector to create jobs, increase
            productivity, and promote exports by meeting the
            requirements of Dominican Republic - Central America free
            trade agreement (DR-CAFTA).

docna.cdata!:
Reducir la burocracia mejora el entorno para
            hacer negocios en Nicaragua

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Competitiveness Learning and
            Innovation Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Competitiveness
            Learning and Innovation Loan Project in Nicaragua were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to global
            environment outcome was low or negligible, and the Bank and
            Borrower performances were both satisfactory. Some of the
            key lessons learned during project implementation were: (1)
            Cluster organizations can be an effective mechanism to
            improve public-private dialogue and bring private sector
            concerns to bear on public policy. The
            "intangible" benefits of the cluster approach are
            important: greater awareness of constraints to private
            sector development, better linkages, more confidence and
            cooperation among private and public stakeholders, and
            changes in business attitudes. At the same time, concerns
            raised by the private sector should represent the broad
            interests of the sector rather than specific benefits to
            individual firms. (2) The competitiveness agenda needs
            high-level political support and coordination across the
            many public sector agencies involved. (3) Initiatives taken
            by cluster organizations should be focused, guided by a
            conceptual framework, and proactive rather than reactive.
            Cluster activities should be integrated with efforts to
            improve the investment climate. Particularly with a limited
            budget, there is a risk of dispersion of effort across many
            small initiatives, with the end result of low impact. (4)
            Reforms in the policy and institutional environment require
            engagement with the legislative branch early in the process,
            not just at the end of the process when a draft bill is
            presented. (5) Especially in a Learning and Innovation Plan,
            a results-oriented Method and Evaluation system is critical..

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Competitiveness Learning and
            Innovation Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Competitiveness Learning and
            Innovation Loan Project in Nicaragua will test
            private-public partnerships for developing consensus, and
            introducing reform on business issues, and will pilot
            information technology-based business development services
            (BDS). Project components will: 1) develop inclusive
            business clusters, through contract service providers to
            facilitate, and identify cross-cluster business environment
            constraints, and reform proposals, improve productivity, and
            develop operational plans. The component will also pilot
            sustainable information technology (IT) based BDS, through
            technical assistance provision, and equipment/software
            supply for the development of an IT business development
            center, which will provide training, quality assurance,
            export facilitation, design assistance, and information on
            financing for micro and small businesses; 2) pilot reforms
            for competitiveness policies, institutions and
            administrative procedures related to private sector
            development. Consensus will be built for incorporating the
            private sector in the management of public training system,
            assess alternatives, and monitor implementation. Innovations
            on domestic competition will be tested, addressing best
            practices, deregulation, and consumer protection, as well as
            investment promotion activities; and 3) increase
            public-private management capacity on competition policy.
